label: Demand Forecasting & Capacity Planning
description: ML-powered continuous workforce demand forecasting based on business growth plans, revenue targets, and operational metrics with capacity analysis by role, department, and skill to enable proactive hiring and resource allocation.

traditional.workflow: 1. Annual headcount planning during budgeting cycle (once per year). 2. Department managers submit headcount requests in spreadsheets: 'Need 5 more engineers, 3 salespeople'. 3. Finance reviews requests, cuts 20-30% based on budget constraints. 4. HR receives approved headcount plan in January for entire year. 5. No adjustments during year: business changes but headcount plan remains static. 6. Hiring reactive: scramble to backfill unexpected departures or support unplanned initiatives.
constraints: Annual planning cycle: headcount needs forecasted once per year, quickly outdated
Budget-driven vs business-driven: headcount cut to fit budget, not aligned to strategic growth
No continuous forecasting: can't adjust for business changes (new products, M&A, market shifts)
Capacity constraints discovered reactively: projects delayed due to lack of resources
No skill-based planning: know need '10 engineers' but not Java vs Python vs DevOps skills
Forecast accuracy: 60-70% (annual plan doesn't reflect reality)
No proactive hiring: always behind curve due to static annual plan

agentic.workflow: 1. Demand Forecasting & Capacity Planning Agent continuously predicts workforce needs based on: revenue growth plans, product launch schedules, customer acquisition targets, operational metrics (sales per rep, customers per support agent). 2. Agent analyzes capacity constraints by department and role: 'Engineering at 95% capacity, bottleneck for Q3 product launches'. 3. Agent forecasts demand by skill: 'Need 8 Python engineers, 3 DevOps, 2 ML specialists in next 6 months'. 4. Agent integrates with financial planning (FP&A): aligns workforce plan to revenue forecast and budget. 5. Agent recommends hiring priorities: roles with highest business impact and longest lead time to fill. 6. Agent adjusts forecast monthly: incorporates business changes (deal wins, project delays, attrition). 7. Agent generates executive summary: headcount forecast, budget impact, hiring roadmap, capacity risks.
dataSources: Business growth plans and revenue targets
Operational metrics (sales per rep, support tickets per agent)
Current workforce data (headcount, roles, skills, capacity utilization)
Historical hiring data (time-to-fill, offer acceptance rates)
benefits: 85-90% forecast accuracy vs 60-70% traditional (continuous updates vs annual plan)
Proactive hiring: start recruiting 3-6 months ahead of need vs reactive backfilling
Business-aligned headcount: tied to revenue growth and product plans, not just budget cuts
Capacity visibility: identify bottlenecks before projects delayed
Skills-based planning: forecast Python engineers vs generic 'engineers' for targeted recruiting
Monthly forecast updates: adjust for business changes vs static annual plan
Executive alignment: CFO, COO, and CHRO aligned on workforce strategy

quickWins: Deploy continuous headcount forecasting for high-growth departments (engineering, sales)
Integrate workforce planning with FP&A revenue forecasts
Implement capacity analysis dashboards for executive visibility
prerequisites: HRIS integration with headcount and role data
Business metrics (revenue, product roadmaps, operational KPIs)

label: Attrition Prediction & Retention
description: ML-powered prediction of voluntary turnover risk 60-90 days in advance with 70-80% accuracy, identifying flight risk factors, and triggering proactive retention interventions to reduce voluntary attrition by 20-40%.

traditional.workflow: 1. Employee submits resignation: 2-week notice standard. 2. Manager surprised: had no warning employee was unhappy or job hunting. 3. HR conducts exit interview: asks why employee leaving (too late to retain). 4. HR analyzes attrition data quarterly: identifies trends 3-6 months after the fact. 5. Retention efforts reactive: only after key employees already resigned. 6. No prediction of which employees at risk of leaving.
constraints: Reactive retention: employees already resigned before action taken
Exit interviews too late: capture reasons after departure decision made
No flight risk prediction: managers surprised when key employees leave
Quarterly attrition analysis: 3-6 months lag, patterns identified too late to intervene
Retention interventions ad-hoc: counter-offers made emotionally, not strategically
Cost of attrition: 1.5-2x salary to replace (recruiting, training, productivity loss)
Key talent loss: no prioritization of retention efforts by employee value

agentic.workflow: 1. Attrition Prediction & Retention Agent uses ML model to predict flight risk 60-90 days before resignation with 70-80% accuracy. 2. Agent analyzes predictive factors: declining engagement scores, reduced collaboration (email/Slack activity), no recent promotion or raise, manager relationship issues, below-market compensation, LinkedIn profile updates. 3. Agent scores employees 0-100 for flight risk: flags high-risk employees (score >70) for proactive intervention. 4. Agent recommends retention actions by risk factor: compensation adjustment (if below market), promotion/career development (if stalled), manager coaching (if relationship issue), flexible work (if work-life balance concern). 5. Agent triggers stay conversations: manager or HR meets with employee before resignation to address concerns. 6. Agent tracks retention intervention effectiveness: which actions work, refine model over time. 7. Agent calculates retention ROI: cost of retention actions vs cost of replacement.
dataSources: Employee engagement survey responses and trends
Historical attrition data (who left, when, why)
benefits: 70-80% attrition prediction accuracy: identify flight risk 60-90 days before resignation
20-40% voluntary turnover reduction through proactive retention interventions
Retention intervention success: 60-70% vs 20-30% reactive counter-offers
Cost savings: avoid 1.5-2x salary replacement costs (recruiting, training, productivity loss)
Prioritized retention: focus on high-value employees vs scattershot approach
Manager coaching: equip managers with flight risk alerts and retention playbooks
Continuous learning: ML model improves over time, identifies new attrition patterns

hitlGate.threshold: Retention interventions for high-value employees (executives, key technical leaders)
hitlGate.policy: HR leadership and executives must review and approve retention interventions for high-value employees including compensation adjustments, promotions, or equity grants; AI provides recommendations but humans make final decisions

quickWins: Deploy attrition prediction model for high-value employees (executives, key technical roles)
Integrate engagement survey data for flight risk signals
Train managers on proactive stay conversations with at-risk employees
transformationGuidance.timeToValue: 9-12 months (requires 24+ months historical attrition data for ML training)
prerequisites: Historical attrition data (24+ months: who left, when, why)

label: Skills & Competency Analytics
description: Real-time skills graph mapping employee capabilities against current and future role requirements with AI-powered gap analysis, skills inference from work performed, and development recommendations for reskilling and upskilling.

traditional.workflow: 1. Annual skills inventory: HR sends spreadsheet survey to all employees asking to list skills. 2. Employees self-report skills with no validation: inflated ratings, out-of-date information. 3. Skills data stored in spreadsheets or HRIS but rarely analyzed. 4. Skills gaps discovered when project staffing fails: 'Need Python developer but realize no one has this skill'. 5. Learning & development decisions made without skills data: generic training vs targeted reskilling. 6. Succession planning lacks skills visibility: don't know who can step into critical roles.
constraints: Annual skills inventory: data 1-12 months out of date
Self-reported skills: inflated ratings, no validation, 0-20% accuracy
Skills data not analyzed: captured but not used for decision-making
Reactive skills gaps: discovered when projects stall or roles can't be filled
No skills-based development: training generic vs targeted to actual gaps
No skills inference: can't identify hidden skills from work performed
Skills taxonomy fragmented: different departments define skills differently

agentic.workflow: 1. Skills & Competency Analytics Agent maintains real-time skills graph for all employees: maps skills to roles, projects, teams, and individuals. 2. Agent infers skills from work performed: code commits (Python, Java), certifications earned, projects completed, training taken, tools used (Salesforce, Tableau). 3. Agent validates self-reported skills: compares to inferred skills, flags discrepancies for verification. 4. Agent analyzes skills gaps: compares current employee skills vs role requirements, identifies gaps by team and role. 5. Agent forecasts future skills needs: analyzes strategic initiatives (AI/ML projects, cloud migration), identifies required skills. 6. Agent recommends development: personalized learning plans, reskilling programs, external hiring vs internal training. 7. Agent enables skills-based talent mobility: matches employees to open roles and projects based on skills vs job titles.
dataSources: Learning Management System data (courses completed, certifications)
Project management data (projects worked on, roles)
Code repository activity (GitHub, GitLab commits, languages used)
Strategic initiatives and future skills needs
benefits: 100% skills visibility vs 0-20% traditional: know who has what skills in real-time
Skills-based development: targeted reskilling vs generic training (40% cost savings)
Proactive skills gap closure: identify and address gaps 6-12 months before critical
Skills inference: discover hidden employee capabilities from work performed
Validated skills data: inferred skills more accurate than self-reported
Skills-based talent mobility: match employees to roles by skills vs job titles
Build vs buy decisions: know when to reskill existing employees vs hire externally

quickWins: Deploy skills inference for technical roles (analyze code commits, certifications)
Implement skills gap analysis for critical skills (AI/ML, cloud, data science)
Create skills-based talent marketplace for internal mobility
prerequisites: HRIS integration with role and employee data

label: Succession Planning & Talent Mobility
description: AI-powered identification of high-potential employees and creation of dynamic succession plans for critical roles with 80%+ coverage, internal talent marketplace for mobility, and career pathing recommendations.

traditional.workflow: 1. Annual succession planning exercise: HR identifies 20-30 critical executive roles. 2. Executives nominate potential successors: 1-2 names per role in spreadsheet. 3. Succession plan stored in spreadsheet or PowerPoint: updated annually if at all. 4. 20-30% of critical roles have identified successors (low coverage). 5. Internal mobility ad-hoc: employees hear about open roles via grapevine, not systematic. 6. When key executive leaves: scramble to backfill externally due to lack of prepared successors.
constraints: Annual succession planning: plans outdated within months as people change roles
Low coverage: 20-30% of critical roles have successors identified
Static successor pools: don't adjust for employee development or departures
Executive-nominated successors: biased toward 'mini-me' selections, limited diversity
Internal mobility invisible: employees don't know about opportunities in other departments
Career pathing manual: employees ask 'How do I get promoted?' with no clear answer
External backfilling expensive: lack of succession planning forces costly external hires

agentic.workflow: 1. Succession & Talent Mobility Agent identifies high-potential employees using ML model: performance ratings, leadership competencies, skills breadth, learning agility, engagement. 2. Agent creates dynamic succession plans for critical roles: 3-5 potential successors per role, readiness assessment (ready now, 1-2 years, 2-3 years). 3. Agent monitors successor readiness: tracks development plans, skills growth, stretch assignments. 4. Agent recommends development actions: 'Successor A needs finance exposure, assign to budget committee'. 5. Agent maintains internal talent marketplace: matches employees to open roles across company based on skills, career interests, development goals. 6. Agent provides career pathing: shows employees how to progress from current role to target role (skills needed, typical timeline, development actions). 7. Agent tracks internal mobility: dashboards show internal fill rate, promotion rates, talent flow across departments.
dataSources: Learning agility and growth potential indicators
Open positions and internal job postings
Career interests and aspirations (from development conversations)
benefits: 80%+ succession coverage: 80-90% of critical roles have 3-5 identified successors vs 20-30% traditional
50-60 point increase in succession coverage: dramatically reduces external backfilling risk
Dynamic succession plans: update quarterly vs annually, adjust for employee changes
Data-driven successor identification: ML model reduces bias, identifies diverse successors
Internal fill rate increases 2-3x: 70-80% vs 30-40% through talent marketplace
Career path visibility: employees see clear progression paths, increasing engagement and retention
40-60% retention improvement: internal mobility reduces turnover (employees stay for new opportunities)

quickWins: Identify high-potential employees using performance and leadership data
Create succession plans for top 50 critical roles
Launch internal talent marketplace for job postings and skills-based matching
prerequisites: Critical role definitions (which roles are succession-critical)

label: Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Analytics
description: Real-time diversity dashboards tracking representation across levels and departments, pay equity analysis with regression modeling, promotion equity monitoring, and forecasting to identify and close diversity gaps proactively.

traditional.workflow: 1. Annual EEO-1 report: HR compiles diversity data once per year for compliance filing. 2. Diversity presented to board annually: high-level summary (% women, % underrepresented minorities). 3. Pay equity analysis ad-hoc: run every 2-3 years when legal/HR concerned about risk. 4. Promotion equity not tracked: don't know if diverse employees promoted at same rate. 5. Diversity goals set but not measured throughout year: discovered in December goals missed. 6. No root cause analysis: know representation low but don't know why (hiring, promotion, attrition).
constraints: Annual diversity reporting: 12-month lag, can't course-correct mid-year
Compliance-focused: EEO-1 filing requirement, not strategic diversity management
Pay equity analysis rare: 2-3 year intervals, gaps exist undetected for years
Promotion equity blind spot: don't track if diverse employees promoted fairly
No representation forecasting: don't know if current trends will close diversity gaps
Root cause unknown: know diversity low but not whether hiring, promotion, or retention issue
Diversity goals aspirational: set but not measured or managed to achieve

agentic.workflow: 1. Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Agent generates real-time diversity dashboards: representation by gender, race, veteran status across levels (IC, manager, director, VP, executive) and departments. 2. Agent tracks hiring diversity: applicant demographics, offer rates, acceptance rates by demographic. 3. Agent analyzes promotion equity: compares promotion rates across demographics, flags statistically significant disparities. 4. Agent performs pay equity analysis using regression modeling: identifies pay gaps after controlling for role, level, tenure, location, performance. 5. Agent forecasts diversity trends: projects representation in 1-3 years based on current hiring, promotion, and attrition patterns. 6. Agent recommends actions: 'Women promotion rate 15% below men at manager level—investigate and address'. 7. Agent tracks progress toward diversity goals: monthly updates, alerts when off-track.
dataSources: Employee demographics (gender, race, ethnicity, veteran status, disability)
Hiring data (applicants, offers, acceptances by demographics)
Promotion rates and timing by demographics
Compensation data (salary, bonus, equity by demographics)
Market data for pay equity benchmarking
benefits: Real-time diversity visibility: monthly dashboards vs annual reports enable proactive management
Pay equity compliance: proactive gap analysis vs reactive legal risk management
Promotion equity monitoring: identify and fix disparities before they compound
Diversity forecasting: know if current trends will achieve goals, adjust strategies accordingly
Root cause analysis: identify whether diversity gaps due to hiring, promotion, or retention
Data-driven DE&I strategy: move from aspirational goals to measurable actions
Legal risk reduction: proactive pay equity analysis reduces discrimination liability

quickWins: Deploy real-time diversity dashboard for executives
Perform pay equity regression analysis quarterly
Track promotion rates by demographics to identify disparities
prerequisites: Clean employee demographic data (self-reported via EEOC forms)

label: Talent Mobility & Internal Marketplace
description: AI-powered internal job marketplace with skills-based matching recommendations, career development opportunities, gig assignments, and talent visibility enabling 2-3x increase in internal fill rates and 40-60% retention improvement.

traditional.workflow: 1. Internal job openings posted to company intranet: generic job board listing. 2. Employees learn about opportunities via word-of-mouth or browsing intranet. 3. Manager permission required: employees ask manager before applying internally. 4. Internal applicants compete with external: no preference or visibility for internal candidates. 5. Hiring managers often unaware of internal talent: default to external recruiting. 6. Internal mobility rate: 30-40% of roles filled internally. 7. Cross-functional opportunities hidden: employees siloed in departments, unaware of options elsewhere.
constraints: Hidden opportunities: employees don't know about internal openings beyond their department
Manager gatekeeping: employees need permission to apply internally, limiting mobility
No skills-based matching: employees search by job title, miss roles matching their skills
Internal candidates invisible: hiring managers default to external recruiting, overlook internal talent
Low internal fill rate: 30-40% vs 70-80% potential with better talent mobility
Career stagnation: employees don't see growth opportunities internally, leave for external roles
Siloed talent: skills and experience trapped in departments, not leveraged across company
metrics: Internal mobility barriers: Manager permission required

agentic.workflow: 1. Talent Mobility Agent maintains internal talent marketplace: all open roles, gig projects, stretch assignments visible to all employees. 2. Agent recommends roles to employees: 'Based on your Python skills and product management experience, these 5 roles are a great fit'. 3. Agent recommends employees to hiring managers: 'These 8 internal candidates match your role requirements, consider interviewing before external search'. 4. Agent enables confidential job exploration: employees browse opportunities without alerting manager. 5. Agent facilitates gig assignments: short-term projects (2-6 months) for skill development without changing roles. 6. Agent tracks career interests: 'You said you want to move into data science—here are 3 stretch assignments to build skills'. 7. Agent measures internal mobility: dashboards show internal fill rate, promotion rates, talent flow across departments.
dataSources: Open internal job postings and role requirements
Employee skills profiles and career interests
Gig projects and stretch assignment opportunities
Hiring manager preferences and role criteria
Employee career goals and development plans
benefits: 2-3x internal fill rate: 70-80% vs 30-40% through skills-based matching and talent visibility
40-60% retention improvement: employees stay for internal growth opportunities vs leaving externally
Faster time-to-productivity: internal hires 30-50% faster to ramp than external hires
Cost savings: internal hires cost $5K-$15K vs $50K-$100K external recruiting costs
Skills-based matching: employees discover roles they didn't know existed
Manager support: AI recommendations reduce manager fear of losing talent (backfill visibility)
Career development: gig assignments enable skill-building without role changes
metrics: Recruiting cost savings: $45K-$85K per internal hire

quickWins: Launch internal talent marketplace with all open roles visible
Implement skills-based job recommendations for employees
Enable confidential job exploration without manager gatekeeping
prerequisites: Internal job posting system (ATS or HRIS)
Executive sponsorship for open internal mobility (no manager gatekeeping)
Hiring manager training on internal candidate consideration

label: Scenario Planning & What-If Analysis
description: Real-time workforce modeling and scenario analysis tools enabling executives to simulate impact of business changes (growth, reorganizations, M&A) on headcount, costs, skills, and capacity with sensitivity analysis on key drivers.

traditional.workflow: 1. Annual budget scenario planning: CFO requests 3 scenarios (pessimistic, base, optimistic). 2. HR manually builds Excel models: projects headcount by scenario over 3-5 days. 3. Scenarios static: once built, not updated for business changes. 4. What-if questions ad-hoc: executive asks 'What if we acquire Company X?', HR scrambles to build model. 5. Limited sensitivity analysis: don't know impact of changing key assumptions (attrition, hiring speed). 6. Workforce model disconnected from financial model: HR headcount plan doesn't tie to CFO revenue/cost forecast.
constraints: Static Excel models: built for annual budget, quickly outdated
Manual scenario building: 3-5 days to model each scenario
Limited scenario coverage: 3 scenarios per year vs continuous what-if exploration
No sensitivity analysis: don't know which assumptions most impact outcomes
Ad-hoc executive requests: scramble to answer 'what if?' questions in board meetings
Workforce-finance disconnect: HR plan doesn't integrate with CFO financial model
No real-time scenario comparison: can't quickly model multiple strategic options
metrics: Model build time: 3-5 days per scenario

agentic.workflow: 1. Scenario Planning Agent provides real-time workforce modeling tool for executives: self-service interface to build scenarios. 2. Agent models business scenarios: revenue growth (10%, 20%, 30%), acquisitions (add 500 employees from Company X), reorganizations (consolidate 3 departments into 2), market downturns (15% headcount reduction). 3. Agent calculates scenario impact: headcount by role and department, total labor cost, skills gaps, capacity constraints, hiring lead time. 4. Agent performs sensitivity analysis: shows which assumptions most impact outcomes (attrition rate, hiring speed, revenue per employee). 5. Agent integrates with financial planning: workforce costs tie directly to CFO revenue forecast and budget. 6. Agent compares scenarios side-by-side: helps executives choose optimal strategy. 7. Agent tracks scenario accuracy: compares forecasted vs actual outcomes, improves model over time.
dataSources: Current workforce data (headcount, roles, skills, costs)
Business growth plans and revenue targets
Historical scenario outcomes for model validation
benefits: Real-time scenario modeling: hours vs 3-5 days per scenario enables agile decision-making
Unlimited scenario exploration: executives model multiple strategic options before committing
Sensitivity analysis: identify critical assumptions (e.g., 'Attrition rate matters more than hiring speed')
Workforce-finance integration: labor costs tied to revenue forecast, CFO and CHRO aligned
Strategic agility: quickly evaluate M&A, reorganizations, market changes
Data-driven workforce strategy: move from gut-feel to quantitative scenario comparison
Board readiness: answer 'what if?' questions in real-time during board meetings
metrics: Scenario modeling time: <1 hour vs 3-5 days
Scenario coverage: Unlimited vs 3 per year

quickWins: Build scenario planning tool for top 3 business scenarios (growth, downturn, M&A)
Integrate workforce plan with financial planning (FP&A) system
Perform sensitivity analysis on key assumptions (attrition, hiring speed)
prerequisites: HRIS integration with headcount and cost data
Workforce modeling platform or custom tool development
